What is Open Research?

Open research involves approaches to conducting and disseminating research in a way that makes it open, transparent, and accessible to everyone in society.
Open research incorporates a range of actions taken at all stages of the research cycle.
Open research helps to make all aspects of the research process more transparent and helps make knowledge generated by research publicly available.

Many people have heard the term open science. Open science can be defined as the movement to make scientific research, data, and dissemination accessible to all levels of an inquiring society. It can also be viewed as research simply done properly.
In this course, we use the term open research instead of open science. This reflects the inclusion of all disciplines in which research is conducted.
Some aspects and practices of open research can differ depending on the area you are studying. This introductory course will help you identify what aspects are useful overall and for your specific context.
There are five schools of thought about open research.

The infrastructure school relates to making research platforms, tools, and services openly available.
The pragmatic school relates to enhancing efficiency of knowledge creation and research.
The public school relates to making research accessible to the public.
The democratic school relates to making knowledge available to everyone.
And the measurement school relates to developing and using alternative approaches to measuring impact.

title: 1.2 History of Open Research
text:
Methodological issues and questionable research practices
Skip ahead to watch the video presentation
See the slides
Did you know the internet was originally designed for research purposes? Researchers wanted a fast, easy, and low-cost way of sharing data with each other. So the internet was born. Now the internet dominates almost all aspects of our daily lives. Yet it has deviated from its original purpose.
Open research is the movement to bring modern research back in line with its original digital intent.
The open access movement began in the early 1990s with the aim to make research products available to everyone including the general public.
Improving transparency and reproducibility relates to making research processes and outputs more open so other researchers could examine and reproduce them.
The open science movement was aimed at correcting bad science and restoring public trust in scientific research.
Open research. It became evident that more open research practices could apply across disciplines, not just in science. This would ensure reproducibility, transparency, and collaboration across disciplines.
Open research methods are still evolving within the sciences, and some disciplines are just beginning to develop open research methods that suit their subjects.
Part of the move towards open research was driven by problems that were becoming apparent in the scientific literature.
Open research partly emerged in response to methodological crisis whereby it was not possible to replicate or reproduce many scientific studies and findings. This reproducibility crisis or replicability crisis has been most commonly reported in psychology and some areas of health and medicine.
For example, in one survey of over 1,500 researchers, more than 70% had tried and failed to reproduce another researcherâ€™s findings, and more than half had failed to reproduce their own findings.
Open research also aims to address questionable research practices.

title: 1.2 History of Open Research
text:
What are questionable research practices?

They are practices and techniques that do not follow best research practice.
They can be used to get a desired research result or report research findings in a more favorable manner.
They undermine trust and confidence in research findings.
They introduce bias to research processes and findings.

Questionable research practices can take place at any stage of the research process.
Selective reporting involves cherry-picking and publishing only findings that are novel, exciting, or statistically significant.
Underspecified methods involves not sharing methods with other researchers in enough detail so that they can attempt to replicate it. Data dredging, exploiting the data to achieve novel, exciting or statistically significant results, HARKing, hypothesizing after results are known, reporting unexpected findings as though they were expected from the start.

Why do researchers engage in Q or Ps?
Bad science is not always conducted by bad researchers. So why does it happen? The perception that more research outputs is better creates pressure to publish. This can negatively impact how people do research. They may cut corners to get more research published. Profit motives or ideological commitments might make researchers engage in poor practices.
Poor research practices might also just reflect how researchers were taught in the first place.
Researchers can also just make mistakes. As a student, it can be easy to engage in QRPs. If I think exciting or significant results will lead to a better grade, I might engage in questionable research practices. Time constraints and coursework pressures can also lead to cutting corners.
It is important to guard against questionable research practices in all your research activities. This ensures the research you conduct is robust and trustworthy.
Increased and ongoing awareness of issues around reproducibility and QRPs has led to improved open research practices. Open research practices can improve the validity and integrity of research. Though poor methods exist, open research aims to improve them. It is these practices and the underlying principles of open research that we will introduce you to in this course.
Did you know making and having open research is so important that it is in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights? According to this document, everyone has the right to freely participate in the cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts, and to share in scientific advancement and its benefits. Everyone has the right to the protection of the moral and material interests resulting from any scientific, literary, or artistic production where they are the author.

Why is open research important?
Benefits of open research for research include: - Increased research transparency and reproducibility - Enhanced accessibility and reusability of data - Less poor research practices and greater research accountability - Increased opportunities for research collaboration - Improved visibility of research findings - Encouragement of broader society participation in research
How does open research increase transparency and reproducibility of research outputs? In what ways does open research increase transparency and reproducibility of research outputs? By being very clear and outlining exactly what was done and how it was done. This can include clearly stating what, when, and or how archives or repositories were searched to identify research documents.
It could also include clearly outlining all steps in an experimental study and/or all the steps and statistical code used to analyze data.
How does open research increase transparency and reproducibility of research outputs? Open research also encourages researchers to share their data with other researchers.
Data is information collected, recorded, or created during the research process to validate research findings.
Data can be made available on online repositories. Open data helps other researchers to independently validate or attempt to reproduce the research.

section: Enhanced accessibility and reusability of data
text:
Enhanced accessibility and reusability of data
What is open data? Open data is research data that anyone can use, access, and share.
Research data is information collected, generated, recorded, or used to validate or underpin the primary findings of a research project or study.
Data can exist in many formats like images, data sets, musical compositions, guidelines, multimedia, code, software, and more. Making data open and available is an important part of open research.
What is open data? In the past, open data has not been the norm. Technological developments have removed many of the barriers to sharing data.
Open data is not yet universal, but is increasingly standard practice. Open data requires a minimum standard of data quality to ensure its reusability. Adoption of minimum standards for open data is still in its infancy. But as the culture of open research grows, so too does the development of open data standards.
How does open data facilitate data accessibility and reusability?

By making data open, researchers are enhancing the reproducibility and transparency of their research outputs.
Making data open means data can be accessed by and presented to a larger audience.
The data can be reused by different researchers over time to answer new research questions.
Making data open can save time in data collection and maximizes research resources.

title: 1.3 Why is open research important
section: Less poor research practices and greater research accountability
text:
Less poor research practices and greater research accountability
How does open research discourage poor research practices? Open research encourages researchers to publicly disclose the details of their methods. These can then be reviewed, assessed, and validated by other researchers. This may discourage use of questionable research practices.
How does open research help us identify methodological issues in research? The case of Covid 19. The Covid 19 pandemic provides a stark example of the ways poor research design can lead to poor outcomes. It also shows how open research can help us identify invalid results before they become the basis for bad clinical practice.
For example, during the pandemic, a trial was conducted to assess the use of hydroxychloricquin, an antimmalarial drug to treat severe CO 19. The study reported reduced mortality in patients who received the drug. As a result, hydroxychloricquin began to be touted as a cure.
But when a preprint of the study was published and other researchers began to review it, they identified a major flaw in the study design. This flaw likely affected the results. So the paper was withdrawn and hydroxychloricquin is not an approved treatment for Covid 19.

title: 1.3 Why is open research important
text:
Increased opportunities for research collaboration
How does open research encourage collaboration? Open research enhances worldwide and interdisciplinary collaboration among researchers. This is facilitated by: 1. Open data whereby data of any kind is openly accessible. 2. Collaborative platforms for sharing information, tools, and resources.
Open research collaboration accelerates discovery and design by bringing together knowledge, tools, and expertise.
How does open research encourage collaboration, the case of Covid 19? During the pandemic, researchers from across the globe collaborated and shared data to better understand the disease and work towards preventive and treatment approaches.
There are also open research repositories dedicated specifically to Covid 19 research. For example, the World Economic Forum Global Science Collaboration Covid 19.

title: 1.3 Why is open research important
section: Encouragement of broader society participation in research
text:
Encouragement of broader society participation in research
How does open research encourage societal participation in research?
Including members of the public when conducting research is important for a number of reasons.

It enhances the relevance and impact of your research.
It helps to ensure fair access to knowledge and reduce inequalities.
Inclusion of the public in conducting research is called citizen research.

How does open research encourage societal participation in research?

Open research findings and outputs can be freely accessed by the public. This means there are no fees or need to use an institutional login.
Open research makes it easier for research to reach the public. This means people outside academia can engage with research outputs.
It is not just research papers that can be made freely available. Textbooks can be made openly available too. For example, via open textbook library.

Sharing of knowledge in open research also involves non-traditional roots including social media, public talks, blogs, visuals, and infographics. Using diverse approaches to share knowledge and research increases the likelihood that people can and will engage with it.

title: 1.3 Why is open research important
section: Why is open research important for me?
text:
Why is open research important for me?
We come across research findings every day in the news, on television, and online. Having a better understanding of open research allows you to better engage with the research you read and hear about.
Understanding good practices and spotting bad practices means you can judge how reliable and trustworthy a piece of research is.
If you go on to apply for a masterâ€™s or PhD funding, research funders increasingly require open research practices for grant applications.
If you decide to publish your project, many journals now encourage open practices, including registering studies in advance and sharing data. Some journals also award badges for open research practices.
Sharing your research also means itâ€™s more likely to be read and or engaged with, meaning you have a greater chance of making an impact with your research.
By sharing drafts of research early, you can get feedback from researchers all over the world to help improve your research. This can be scary, but it can also be worth it.
Sharing data and research materials online also means they can be cited by other researchers because they are assigned digital object identifiers, DOIs.
How often your work is cited is an academic metric that is often used to decide on job opportunities and promotions.
If you use open research approaches, future prospective employers will be able to see your research outputs and processes. This can enhance your job applications, including outside research in academia.

Research integrity

What does open research involve? Open research practices. Now that you have a sense of what open research is about in terms of the principles of open research, we will provide an introduction to using open research practices.
Principles include transparency, reproducibility, accountability, collaboration, and societal engagement.
Practices include research integrity, pre-registration, reproducible practices, research data management, open reporting, and knowledge dissemination.
Open research practices. Open research practices or methods are relevant at all stages of the research process, including research planning, data collection, data analysis, writing up and publishing findings, and disseminating and sharing your research.
Each of the open research practices introduced here are discussed in the next sections.
Guiding principles of research integrity.
Research integrity involves making honest and responsible decisions at all stages of the research cycle. It prioritizes reliability, ensuring quality of research at all stages of the research process, honesty, developing, conducting, sharing, and engaging with research in fair, transparent ways.
Respect for research participants, colleagues, society, culture, and the environment. And accountability for the research, its management, and for wider impacts.
Why is research integrity important?
1. It reduces the likelihood of research misconduct.
2. It ensures the validity of research results.
3. It facilitates trust between researchers. 4. It promotes trust in data and research expertise.

What does open research involve? Open research practices. Now that you have a sense of what open research is about in terms of the principles of open research, we will provide an introduction to using open research practices.
Principles include transparency, reproducibility, accountability, collaboration, and societal engagement.
Practices include research integrity, pre-registration, reproducible practices, research data management, open reporting, and knowledge dissemination.
Open research practices. Open research practices or methods are relevant at all stages of the research process, including research planning, data collection, data analysis, writing up and publishing findings, and disseminating and sharing your research.
Each of the open research practices introduced here are discussed in the next sections.
Research integrity
Guiding principles of research integrity.
Research integrity involves making honest and responsible decisions at all stages of the research cycle. It prioritizes reliability, ensuring quality of research at all stages of the research process, honesty, developing, conducting, sharing, and engaging with research in fair, transparent ways.
Respect for research participants, colleagues, society, culture, and the environment. And accountability for the research, its management, and for wider impacts.
Why is research integrity important? 1. It reduces the likelihood of research misconduct. 2. It ensures the validity of research results. 3. It facilitates trust between researchers. 4. It promotes trust in data and research expertise.
Pre-registration
A pre-registration is a record of research processes. It is created and shared before data are collected or become accessible. It is a timestamped record of decisions about study design, methods, and analysis. Pre-registration documents should be publicly available. There are dedicated repositories to make pre-registrations available.
Why is pre-registration important? 1. It encourages researchers to identify the goals of their project before collecting any data. 2. It creates accountability in research. 3. It discourages researchers from conducting after the-actalyses to find significant, novel, and or exciting results. 4. It makes research findings easier to find.
Open reporting
Research involves choices and revisions at each stage. Open reporting allows us to make our processes and our outputs transparent.
Open reporting involves providing a full, clear, and specific account of how research was conducted. It is supported by use of open reporting checklists.
Why is open reporting important?

It allows researchers to detail their processes and decisions at all stages of the research cycle.
It enhances other researchers ability to evaluate a studyâ€™s results.
It enhances other researchers abilities to reproduce a studyâ€™s results.
It benefits decision making at individual and societal levels because decisions can be made on transparent processes and findings.

Data management
Data is all information collected, observed, recorded or created throughout the research process. It can include spreadsheets, videos, audios, notes, diaries, images.
Data management. Research data management is the organization, storage and preservation of research data during active research and post project.
A data management plan or DMP is a living document which describes the organization, storage, preservation and potential sharing of research data and is an integral part of open research practice.
Why is data management important?

It helps you keep track of your own work.
It protects against data loss.
It increases research efficiency.
It minimizes errors in data mission.
There are funding and publishing incentives related to data management.
There are institutional and/or legal data management requirements.

Why is open data important?
Remember that open data is data made publicly available. 1. It enhances accountability. 2. It enhances transparency. 3. It enhances reproducibility. 4. It facilitates revisiting and building on existing data. 5. It facilitates better and stronger collaborations. 6. It is better value for the public money that funds much research.
Open knowledge dissemination
Open knowledge dissemination means communicating knowledge gained from research in open and accessible ways. This expands on the traditional approach to sharing research knowledge, which involves publishing it in an academic journal that can often only be accessed by paying a fee.
Approaches to open knowledge dissemination include open access publishing. Anyone can access the published research without paying a fee. Preprints, versions of research papers made available online before being peer-reviewed and published. Repositories, databases people can use to store and access research papers and/or data sets.
Science communication. sharing research in a way that increases appreciation, excitement, understanding and impact of research and data visualization representing data graphically or visually to increase its accessibility.
Why is open knowledge dissemination important?

It increases public access to and interest in research.
It increases the transparency and openness of research.
It helps reshape what is considered important in research and academia.

title: 2. Research Integrity
section: What practices can compromise research integrity?
text:
What practices can compromise research integrity?
Plagiarism, including self-plagiarism, giving or taking credit for work inappropriately.
Fabricating data, misrepresenting data, manipulation of images or other materials, undeclared conflicts of interest.

What is plagiarism?
Plagiarism is a practice of misrepresenting someone elseâ€™s words or ideas as your own. It is also possible to self-plagiarize.
This happens when an author passes off old work as new. For example, by submitting one paper for credit in two separate modules.
How do you avoid plagiarism?

Always acknowledge the work and contributions of other people.
When paraphrasing or summarizing someone elseâ€™s work, include a citation.
If including text from someone elseâ€™s work verbatim, use quotation marks and include a citation.
Cite primary sources of information rather than secondary or tertiary sources.

Your university will have resources to help you avoid plagiarism, too. In UCC, for example, a citing, referencing, and plagiarism course is available here.
And check out this video on how to cite sources. And this one on examples of plagiarism. They are short but very useful. Giving or taking credit for work inappropriately.
If someone makes a meaningful contribution to a research project, they should receive credit for their contribution. This might mean they are an author on a final paper or receive an acknowledgement on that paper.
There is guidance to determine if someone makes a meaningful contribution like the IC JME criteria.
You might also ask yourself, did they contribute to the study idea design? Did they conduct analyses or contribute to interpreting findings? Did they assist with writing up the final report paper?
If someone doesnâ€™t make a meaningful contribution, they shouldnâ€™t be given credit. For instance, listing uninvolved members of a research group or more senior academics who only looked at the final paper. These kind of authors are sometimes called ghost authors.


Data fabrication
Data fabrication is a process of manufacturing or making up data. For example, an anthropologist might write transcripts of interviews they never conducted. These transcripts, false data, might become part of the research record.
This can result in unreliable data and waste research resources through attempted replications.
Covid 19 example. A paper published in 2020 reported increased risk of debt for people hospitalized with Covid 19 if they had underlying cardiovascular disease. Findings were based on data supposedly collected by the company of one of the study authors. It quickly became apparent that the data was fraudulent. The paper was retracted, but such questionable practices can undermine trust in research.


Data misrepresentation
Data misrepresentation is a practice of presenting real data in a misleading way. Researchers might emphasize exciting or novel findings only. Researchers might also distort or duplicate images of their findings.
Some researchers even magnified or reverse their images to try and avoid detection. Data misrepresentation gives an incomplete picture of the research findings. Like other questionable research practices, it can result in unreliable data. It can also waste research resources through attempted replications.
Piracy and manipulation of images, other materials
Sometimes researchers manipulate figures, images, or other resources to include them in multiple research papers. Often these manipulated materials come from organizations known as paper mills.
Paper mills turn out fake data, images, and whole papers to meet demand from researchers. But there are also researchers working to identify this manipulated content so it can be retracted.


Undeclared conflicts of interest
A conflict of interest is when a researcherâ€™s other interests lead to intentional or unintentional biases in research.
Conflicts of interest may in turn compromise the validity of the results. For example, a researcher receiving funding for pharmaceutical development may be incentivized to demonstrate that competitors drugs are unsafe or inferior. This may shape how they conduct their research and impact the findings which will influence peopleâ€™s health and care in the future.
Why do people engage in research misconduct?
There are several factors that can motivate research misconduct. Some are emotional like fear of failure. Misconduct may also be motivated by external pressures like pressure from supervisors to achieve a certain result.
Researchers may also feel pressure to perform due to the competitiveness of academic culture. Worries about personal circumstances like employment status might also motivate misconduct.

section: How can you maintain high levels of research integrity?
text:
How can you maintain high levels of research integrity?
How can I help reduce the effects of research misconduct?

Follow best practices in research integrity and open research at all stages of the research process.
Avoid plagiarism.
Accurately and honestly represent your data.
Give credit where it is due.
Be transparent and responsible in all aspects of and decisions about your research.

How can I help reduce the effects of research misconduct?
You can also comment on and review already published papers using platforms like Pubpeer. This helps flag issues in research that are already in the public domain.
Pubier is an online journal club that exists as an app on the Chrome browser. It allows researchers to comment on published journal articles. This is called postpublication peer review.
Researchers can highlight problems in analysis, interpretation, and/or reporting of results. Pubier has contributed to many corrections and retractions of published articles.
Most universities have a research code of conduct that outlines what to do if you suspect research misconduct in your university. Research misconduct can usually be reported in writing to an established research integrity officer in your institution. This is someone trained to follow up and investigate suspected misconduct.

The paper is withdrawn from the journal in which it is published. It may still be available online, but it include a notification that it has been retracted.

Educate yourself about research integrity.
